title: Fiji water quality and ingredients
description: Water quality, testing and ingredients for Fiji water

body.raw: ## Fiji Overview **Oaisys score:** 75 / 100 **Owner and Manufacturer**: Fiji Water Company. **Treatment process**: This water is naturally filtered and replenished by rainfall and volcanic activity in the area, which contributes to its mineral content and taste. The water is botled at source by pumping water through a sealed deliver system free of human contact. The water is filtered to remove any particle matter, micron-filtered to remove microbiological particles, and ultra violet light is applied to ensure disenfection. **Source**: artesian aquifer in the Yaqara Valley of Fiji's main island, Viti Levu. **pH level**: 7.7 **Flouride level**: 0.2 ppm ## Fiji Ingredients - Silica - Calcium, Magnesium and Biocarbonates (Hard water) - Dissolved solids **Effects of Silica** Silica, known scientifically as silicon dioxide (SiO2), is a natural compound found ubiquitously in our environment. It forms when silicon bonds with oxygen and often occurs alongside various minerals. In water, silica appears in two distinct forms: reactive and colloidal. Reactive silica involves monomeric molecules interacting with other substances, whereas colloidal silica consists of tiny, suspended non-porous particles. The Impact of Silica on Human Health - **Neuroprotective Potential**: Research indicates that silica in drinking water might offer protective effects against cognitive decline. Lower silica levels in water have been associated with increased risks of Alzheimer's disease and cognitive impairments, particularly in areas with elevated aluminum concentrations. This suggests that silica could counteract the harmful effects of aluminum on the brain. - **Inherent Safety**: Typically, silica is considered harmless in the small amounts found in drinking water. It is a naturally occurring component in various foods, including grains, vegetables, and fruits. - **Vital Role in Health**: Emerging studies highlight silica's importance in maintaining good health, though it lacks a defined Recommended Daily Intake. Insufficient silica intake can lead to bone deformities, joint issues, reduced collagen production, and imbalanced bone mineralization. - **Low Risk of Toxicity**: There is minimal data on the toxicity of silica in water due to its assumed safety. Animal studies have shown that even high levels (50,000 ppm) of dietary silica do not produce adverse effects, emphasizing its low toxicity. Points of Consideration - **Aesthetic Implications**: High silica content in water can cause scratching and spotting on glassware and fixtures, similar to the effects of hard water. It may also lead to scale buildup in appliances, diminishing their efficiency. - **Taste and Consumption**: Water with high colloidal silica levels can have an unappealing appearance due to floating particles, potentially reducing water consumption and increasing the risk of dehydration. - **Beverage Quality**: When used in brewing tea or coffee, silica particles can react and alter the taste and quality of these beverages. Silica in drinking water is generally safe and might offer significant health benefits, particularly regarding cognitive health. However, its presence is more of an aesthetic concern in daily life. The potential health advantages of silica, along with its essential role in human biology, make it an interesting component of our water sources. _Sources_: [Source 1](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17435954/), [Source 2](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17435951/) **Calcium, Magnesium and Biocarbonates (Hard water)** Calcium and Magnesium, key minerals found in our drinking water, are not just elements on the periodic table but vital players in our daily health. Often found in 'hard water', their roles in our well-being have been the focus of numerous studies. Let's dive into what these minerals mean for our health. Calcium - **Health Necessities**: More than just a bone-builder, calcium is critical for muscle function, nerve signaling, and keeping our blood in check. - **When Lacking**: Watch out for weakened bones (osteoporosis), rickets, and even high blood pressure. - **Water's Gift**: Surprisingly, it can keep those pesky kidney stones at bay. Magnesium - **The Silent Hero**: Powers over 350 enzyme systems, juggles energy production, DNA synthesis, heart health, and hormonal balance. - **Deficiency Dangers**: Low levels can silently usher in osteoporosis, resistance to insulin, metabolic issues, and up the ante for heart diseases. - **CVD Shield**: Our heart's ally, magnesium in water may lower the risk of cardiovascular diseases. Bicarbonates: - **Digestive Aid**: They help neutralize stomach acid, offering relief from indigestion and heartburn. - **pH Balancer**: Bicarbonates assist in maintaining the body’s pH balance, crucial for smooth biological functioning. - **Water Softening**: In water, bicarbonates contribute to temporary hardness, which can be easily removed, improving water quality. The Research - **Varied Voices in Studies**: Research shows a mixed bag – some studies suggest less heart disease with higher water hardness, especially due to magnesium. - **Magnesium's Spotlight**: Some studies pinpoint a drop in heart disease risk with higher magnesium levels in water, especially around 10 mg/L. Nutrition - **The Intake Puzzle**: From one corner of the globe to another, many aren't getting enough of these minerals, with a stark gap in developing regions. - **Absorption Adventures**: How well we absorb these minerals depends on their source – water being a surprisingly efficient one. Health Impacts Unraveled - **Heart Health Harmony**: Magnesium is a maestro in managing heart function and blood vessel health. Low levels can lead to rhythm disturbances. - **Safety First**: Upping calcium and magnesium is generally safe, barring those with significant kidney issues. Water Wisdom - **Remineralizing the Essence**: Especially for desalinated water, adding these minerals back is crucial to prevent pipe damage and maintain nutritional value. - **Taste vs. Health**: Consumer preferences often guide mineral additions in bottled water and beverages. _Sources_: [McGill University](https://www.mcgill.ca/oss/article/health-you-asked/you-asked-hard-water-dangerous-drink#:~:text=Studies%20have%20generally%20found%20hard,it%20comes%20to%20cardiovascular%20disease), [PubMed Article 1](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3775162/), [PubMed Article 2](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC198279/), [American Journal of Hypertension](https://academic.oup.com/ajh/article/12/9/894/351457) **Effects of Dissolved Solids** Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) encompass a variety of substances in water, primarily inorganic salts and some organic matter. These components are critical in assessing water quality and its appropriateness for consumption. Here's an in-depth look at how Dissolved Solids impact human health: Introduction to Total Dissolved Solids - TDS in water comprise both organic and inorganic substances. - They primarily include inorganic salts like calcium, magnesium, potassium, sodium, bicarbonates, chlorides, and sulfates, along with some organic substances. - The measure of TDS, expressed in parts per million (ppm), serves as a key indicator of water quality. Effects on Human Health - **Nutritional Contribution**: Elements like calcium and magnesium in TDS can enhance the nutritional value of water. - **Taste Enhancement**: Water with TDS levels in the range of 300 to 600 ppm is often considered to taste better. - **Essential Minerals**: Moderate amounts of certain TDS elements are crucial for health. Potential Risks - **Excessive TDS Levels**: TDS levels above 500 ppm can deteriorate water taste and may pose health risks. The EPA's recommended maximum is 500 ppm. - **Associated Contaminants**: High TDS levels may coincide with the presence of harmful substances, including heavy metals like lead or arsenic. - **Hard Water Challenges**: Elevated TDS often means hard water, leading to scaling in pipes and appliances. Additional Considerations - **Impact of Water Treatment**: Water purification methods might reduce beneficial minerals in TDS alongside harmful components. - **Importance of Balanced TDS**: Maintaining an optimal TDS level in drinking water is essential for health and taste. In essence, Dissolved Solids in water present a complex scenario. While they are key to imparting essential minerals and affecting water taste, an imbalance, especially in higher concentrations, can have adverse effects on health and home appliances. It's vital to keep TDS levels in check to ensure water quality and safety for everyday use. _Sources_: [WHO Document on TDS](https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/wash-documents/wash-chemicals/tds.pdf?sfvrsn=3e6d651e_4), [WHO Guidelines for Drinking-water Quality](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/44584/9789241548151_eng.pdf), [PubMed Article](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8478203/) # Fiji Full Testing Report A 2016 water analysis report for Fiji Water is listed below. Please note that in the results column of each table “ND” indicates Non-Detected. **Mineral Analysis** | General Mineral Analysis | FIJI Water | | ------------------------ | ----------- | | `,(0,n.jsxDEV)(e.p,{children:"Silica, known scientifically as silicon dioxide (SiO2), is a natural compound found ubiquitously in our environment. It forms when silicon bonds with oxygen and often occurs alongside various minerals. In water, silica appears in two distinct forms: reactive and colloidal. Reactive silica involves monomeric molecules interacting with other substances, whereas colloidal silica consists of tiny, suspended non-porous particles."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-74a86974-a9eb-4ab8-abe9-0c678c3792b3.mdx",lineNumber:40,columnNumber:1},this),`

Lower silica levels in water have been associated with increased risks of Alzheimer's disease and cognitive impairments, particularly in areas with elevated aluminum concentrations. This suggests that silica could counteract the harmful effects of aluminum on the brain."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-74a86974-a9eb-4ab8-abe9-0c678c3792b3.mdx",lineNumber:44,columnNumber:1},this),`

title: Is Flouride in Drinking Water Safe?

body.raw:
## Historical background Hailing from the innovative strides of the early 20th century, fluoride made its grand entrance as a dental health game-changer. Fast forward to the mid-1940s, and it's a mainstay in our nation's crusade against cavities, earning accolades as a triumph in public health. Today, this cavity combatant finds its way into the taps of roughly 75% of American homes. Our water is fortified with various forms of fluoride, from fluorosilicic acid to sodium fluorosilicate, and sodium fluoride, ensuring that every sip comes with a shield against tooth decay. While our natural water bodies like lakes and rivers boast an average fluoride concentration of about 0.2 mg/L, the levels can vary, painting a diverse fluoride landscape across the U.S.
This naturally occurring mineral, lauded for its cavity-fighting abilities, has been a subject of continuous scientific scrutiny. ## Regulation of flouride in drinking water? Since 1962, the United States Public Health Service (PHS) has recommended fluoride concentrations in public water supplies to be maintained between 0.7 and 1.2 mg/L to aid in the prevention of dental cavities. In 2015, this recommendation was adjusted to a single target of 0.7 mg/L of fluoride. This update reflects the increased availability of fluoride from various sources, such as toothpaste, requiring a reassessment to avoid excessive intake. The EPA caps fluoride in public drinking water at 4.0 mg/L. Prolonged exposure above this limit risks skeletal fluorosis, causing joint pain and potential bone weakness or fractures in seniors. To safeguard our kids from dental fluorosis, the EPA recommends capping fluoride levels at 2.0 mg/L. This helps prevent too much fluoride from disrupting normal tooth enamel formation in young smiles. Ensuring the purity of our bottled water, the FDA permits up to 2.4 mg/L of fluoride in non-fluoridated varieties, adapted to colder regions. For those with added fluoride, the cap is set at 0.7 mg/L, aligning with PHS guidelines. According to recent CDC guidelines, the fluoride content in children's toothpaste may be higher than recommended, especially when used in conjunction with fluoridated water. Parents are advised to monitor and manage their children's fluoride intake to prevent possible dental fluorosis, marked by changes in tooth enamel coloration. Moreover, new research indicates that fluoride's role in preventing tooth decay is significantly more impactful during childhood than in adulthood. Hence, the timing of fluoride consumption is crucial for its effectiveness in dental health. ## Possible risks of flouride in drinking water Elevated fluoride intake has been observed to alter tooth enamel, a condition known as dental fluorosis, and may contribute to bone fragility. Emerging studies raise concerns about fluoride's potential neurotoxicity, hinting at a link between high fluoride exposure and cognitive challenges.
**Bone Health Alert**: Persistent fluoride consumption can result in skeletal fluorosis, marked by bone accumulation of fluoride, leading to joint discomfort and increased risk of bone fractures among seniors. **Glandular Impact**: Research indicates fluoride accumulation in the pineal and thyroid glands, possibly disrupting their normal functions. **Tooth Discoloration**: High fluoride levels during teeth development in children can lead to dental fluorosis, noticeable through discolored tooth enamel. **Fluoride Toxicity**: Elevated fluoride levels, often from water sources or supplements, have been associated with a spectrum of health issues. **Additional Health** Implications: Indications of fluoride’s low-dose effects include potential harm to the nervous system, kidneys, and other health aspects: - Neurological Concerns: Fluoride exposure may be correlated with neurological alterations, particularly affecting children's cognitive development. - Kidney Health: Fluoridation at high levels could adversely impact renal function, as kidneys are pivotal in fluoride excretion. - Broader Health Impact: A comprehensive view of fluoride intake reveals possible influences on thyroid health, skeletal integrity, and reproductive health. **Fracture Risk Analysis**: Some evidence suggests that fluoride treatments aimed at countering osteoporosis may not decrease, and could potentially increase, the risk of nonvertebral fractures. Harvard's adjunct professor of environmental health, Philippe Grandjean, acknowledges fluoride's dental benefits but urges caution with its addition to water supplies. He advocates for precise dosing, awareness of its health implications, and attention to sensitive groups, such as infants and dialysis patients, who may require lower fluoride exposure. ## Other sources of flouride
## Conclusion With the ongoing research surrounding flouride most experts agree to limit the amount of flouride consumed and choose topical solutions like toothpaste to get the benefits of flouride. ## References https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/magazine/magazine_article/fluoridated-drinking-water/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6195894/ https://www.cdc.gov/fluoridation/statistics/cost.htm https://bmcoralhealth.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12903-018-0684-2 https://www.newsweek.com/fluoridation-may-not-prevent-cavities-huge-study-shows-348251 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2666911021000216

`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`Our water is fortified with various forms of fluoride, from fluorosilicic acid to sodium fluorosilicate, and sodium fluoride,
ensuring that every sip comes with a shield against tooth decay. While our natural water bodies like lakes and rivers boast an
average fluoride concentration of about 0.2 mg/L, the levels can vary, painting a diverse fluoride landscape across the U.S.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:22,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)("div",{className:"relative overflow-hidden h-full max-w-xl md:pt-4 rounded-lg",children:(0,a.jsxDEV)("img",{src:"https://inruqrymqosbfeygykdx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/website/blog/is-flouride-bad-for-you/cdc-praise.png",alt:"CDC Praise for Flouride in Drinking Water",className:"rounded-lg h-full w-full object-contain object-center"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:27,columnNumber:3},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:26,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)("div",{className:"relative overflow-hidden h-full max-w-xl md:pt-4 rounded-lg",children:(0,a.jsxDEV)("img",{src:"https://inruqrymqosbfeygykdx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/website/blog/is-flouride-bad-for-you/flouride-effect-cavities.png",alt:"Flouride Effect on Tooth Decay",className:"rounded-lg h-full w-full object-contain object-center"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:35,columnNumber:3},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:34,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`This naturally occurring mineral, lauded for its cavity-fighting abilities, has been a subject of
continuous scientific scrutiny.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:42,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.h2,{children:"Regulation of flouride in drinking water?"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:45,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`Since 1962, the United States Public Health Service (PHS) has recommended fluoride concentrations in public water supplies
to be maintained between 0.7 and 1.2 mg/L to aid in the prevention of dental cavities. In 2015,
this recommendation was adjusted to a single target of 0.7 mg/L of fluoride. This update reflects the
increased availability of fluoride from various sources, such as toothpaste, requiring a reassessment to avoid excessive intake.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:47,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`The EPA caps fluoride in public drinking water at 4.0 mg/L. Prolonged exposure above this limit risks skeletal fluorosis,
causing joint pain and potential bone weakness or fractures in seniors.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:52,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`To safeguard our kids from dental fluorosis, the EPA recommends capping fluoride levels at 2.0 mg/L.
This helps prevent too much fluoride from disrupting normal tooth enamel formation in young smiles.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:55,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`Ensuring the purity of our bottled water, the FDA permits up to 2.4 mg/L of fluoride in non-fluoridated varieties,
adapted to colder regions. For those with added fluoride, the cap is set at 0.7 mg/L, aligning with PHS guidelines.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:58,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`According to recent CDC guidelines, the fluoride content in children's toothpaste may be higher than recommended, especially when
used in conjunction with fluoridated water. Parents are advised to monitor and manage their children's fluoride intake to prevent
possible dental fluorosis, marked by changes in tooth enamel coloration.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:61,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:`Moreover, new research indicates that fluoride's role in preventing tooth decay is significantly more impactful during
childhood than in adulthood. Hence, the timing of fluoride consumption is crucial for its effectiveness in dental health.`},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:65,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.h2,{children:"Possible risks of flouride in drinking water"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:68,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:"Elevated fluoride intake has been observed to alter tooth enamel, a condition known as dental fluorosis, and may contribute to bone fragility."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:70,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:"Emerging studies raise concerns about fluoride's potential neurotoxicity, hinting at a link between high fluoride exposure and cognitive challenges."},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:72,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)("div",{className:"relative overflow-hidden h-full max-w-xl md:pt-4 rounded-lg",children:(0,a.jsxDEV)("img",{src:"https://inruqrymqosbfeygykdx.supabase.co/storage/v1/object/public/website/blog/is-flouride-bad-for-you/flouride%20toxicity.jpg",alt:"Flouride Toxicity",className:"rounded-lg h-full w-full object-contain object-center"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:75,columnNumber:3},this)},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:74,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:[(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.strong,{children:"Bone Health Alert"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:82,columnNumber:1},this),": Persistent fluoride consumption can result in skeletal fluorosis, marked by bone accumulation of fluoride, leading to joint discomfort and increased risk of bone fractures among seniors."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:82,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:[(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.strong,{children:"Glandular Impact"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:84,columnNumber:1},this),": Research indicates fluoride accumulation in the pineal and thyroid glands, possibly disrupting their normal functions."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:84,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:[(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.strong,{children:"Tooth Discoloration"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:86,columnNumber:1},this),": High fluoride levels during teeth development in children can lead to dental fluorosis, noticeable through discolored tooth enamel."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:86,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:[(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.strong,{children:"Fluoride Toxicity"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:88,columnNumber:1},this),": Elevated fluoride levels, often from water sources or supplements, have been associated with a spectrum of health issues."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:88,columnNumber:1},this),`
`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:[(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.strong,{children:"Additional Health"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:90,columnNumber:1},this)," Implications: Indications of fluoride\u2019s low-dose effects include potential harm to the nervous system, kidneys, and other health aspects:"]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:90,columnNumber:1},this),`

`,(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.p,{children:[(0,a.jsxDEV)(t.strong,{children:"Fracture Risk Analysis"},void 0,!1,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:96,columnNumber:1},this),": Some evidence suggests that fluoride treatments aimed at countering osteoporosis may not decrease, and could potentially increase, the risk of nonvertebral fractures."]},void 0,!0,{fileName:"/Users/cormachayden/Desktop/apps/oaisys/web/content/blog/_mdx_bundler_entry_point-1aef1430-f2bd-46d6-a253-ffb472dd6dce.mdx",lineNumber:96,columnNumber:1},this),`

title: Los Angeles Department Water Quality
description: Tap water quality of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power

body.raw: ## Overview **Oaisys score:** 15 / 100 **Contaminants exceeding health guidelines**: 9 **Total contaminants**: 30 # Contaminants detected **Arsenic**: 430x health guidelines - Potential effect: skin, bladder, and lung cancers; skin discoloration and lesions. - This source 1.72 ppb - Health Guideline: 0.004 ppb - Legal Limit: 10 ppb **Haloacetic acids (HAA9)**: 184x health guidelines - Potential effect: cancer - This source: 11 ppb - Health Guideline: 0.06 ppb - Legal Limit: none **Total trihalomethanes (TTHMs)**: 177x health guidelines - Potential effect: Linked to bladder and colorectal cancer; may affect liver, kidney, and central nervous system - This source: 26.6 ppb - Health Guideline: 0.15 ppb - Legal Limit: 80 ppb **Haloacetic acids (HAA5)9**: 103x health guidelines - Potential effect: cancer and may impair fetal growth and development. - This source: 10.3 ppb - Health Guideline: 0.1 ppb - Legal Limit: 60 ppb **Chromium (hexavalent)**: 29x health guidelines - Potential effect: anemia, thrombocytopenia, skin conditions, liver dysfunction, renal failure, rhabdomyolysis, dermatitis, hypoglycemia and stomach cancers. - This source: 0.586 ppb - Health Guideline: 0.02 ppb - Legal Limit: none **Nitrate**: 12x health guidelines - Potential effect: cancer risk, thyroid disease, and adverse reproductive outcomes. - This source: 1.69 ppm - Health Guideline: 0.14 ppm - Legal Limit: 10 ppm **Nitrite**: 7.6x health guidelines - Potential effect: possible cancer risk - This source: 1.07 ppm - Health Guideline: 0.14 ppm - Legal Limit: 10 ppm **Bromate**: 7.3x health guidelines - Potential effect: Potential carcinogen and mutagenic (causes mutations in DNA). - This source: 0.735 ppb - Health Guideline: 0.1 ppb - Legal Limit: 10 ppb **Uranium**: 7x health guidelines - Potential effect: kidney damage, respiratory irritation and accumalation of fluid in the lungs, and increased risk of cancer. - This source: 3.00 pCi/L - Health Guideline: 0.43 pCi/L - Legal Limit: 20 pCi/L ## Sources [EWG](https://www.ewg.org/tapwater/system.php?pws=CA1910067) ## Oaisys Page [See full report](https://www.oaisys.ai/blog/los_angeles_tap_water_quality)

title: Primo Water Quality Test Report
description: Is Primo water good for you?

body.raw: ## Primo Overview **Oaisys score:** 50 / 100 **Owner and Manufacturer**: Cott Corporation **Treatment process**: Reverse osmosis, ultraviolet light, and ozonation **Source**: Municipal water supply **pH level**: 9.5 **Flouride level**: 0.6 ppm # Primo Ingredients - Sodium Bicarbonate - Sodium Sulfate **Sodium Bicarbonate** Sodium Bicarbonate, commonly known as baking soda, is a compound that dissolves in water to form sodium and bicarbonate, creating an alkaline solution. This attribute has made it a popular choice for various health-related uses. Let's delve into its impact when consumed in drinking water: - **Neutralizes Stomach Acid**: Its ability to neutralize acid can alleviate conditions like indigestion, which arises from excess stomach acid. This property is beneficial for those suffering from heartburn, providing temporary relief. - **Oral Health**: Small clinical trials have indicated that a sodium bicarbonate rinse can increase saliva pH, making it less acidic. This is crucial for maintaining dental enamel and may be beneficial for individuals with mouth sores or undergoing treatments like chemotherapy. - **Athletic Performance**: Some studies suggest that sodium bicarbonate supplements can enhance performance in high-intensity exercises. However, it's important to note that these effects might also be partly attributed to the placebo effect. - **Kidney Health**: In cases of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease, sodium bicarbonate can help reverse blood acidity. This might slow the progression of chronic kidney disease, although more research is needed for conclusive evidence. Potential Side Effects - **Gastrointestinal Discomfort**: Common side effects include abdominal bloating, nausea, and stomach pain. In some cases, these symptoms can become severe. - **Allergic Reactions**: Although rare, severe allergic reactions to sodium bicarbonate are possible, manifesting as breathing difficulties, itchiness, and rashes. - **Contraindications**: It is advised to avoid sodium bicarbonate for those on sodium-restricted diets, as it increases sodium levels in the bloodstream. Also, excessive use can lead to kidney problems and should be used cautiously, especially in individuals with existing kidney conditions. - **Pregnancy and Breastfeeding**: There is limited data on its safety during pregnancy and breastfeeding. Pregnant individuals may experience fluid buildup and low blood acid levels, making it important to consult healthcare providers before use. Sodium bicarbonate in drinking water can offer several health benefits, particularly in neutralizing stomach acid and improving oral health. However, it's important to be aware of potential side effects and consult with healthcare professionals, especially in cases of existing health conditions or dietary restrictions. _Sources_:[Sodium Bicarbonate - Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/drugs-supplements/sodium-bicarbonate-oral-route-intravenous-route-subcutaneous-route/side-effects/drg-20065950?p=1) **Sodium Sulfate** Sodium Sulfate's presence in drinking water carries a variety of implications for human health. Gaining insight into its effects is crucial for making informed decisions about water consumption and health maintenance. Impact of Sodium Sulfate on Human Health when Found in Drinking Water: - **Alters Taste:** The presence of sodium sulfate can give water a distinct bitter or medicinal flavor, particularly when its concentration exceeds 250 mg/L, which may influence the water's desirability and intake. - **Digestive Reaction:** Initial exposure to water high in sulfate, such as sodium sulfate, can cause a laxative effect, especially in babies and individuals with sensitive stomachs. For this reason, water with sulfate levels below 500 mg/L is recommended for preparing infant formula. - **Habituation Effect:** Adults and older children may gradually become accustomed to higher sulfate levels in water, experiencing fewer digestive disturbances after the initial exposure period. - **Potential Health Risks at Elevated Levels:** Consuming water with excessively high sodium sulfate levels can pose health risks, including dehydration and diarrhea, especially for those not adapted to such concentrations. Note: The effect of sodium sulfate in drinking water varies based on individual health and the specific concentration of this compound. Regular water quality assessments and compliance with established safety guidelines are essential to ensure water safety and promote health. _Sources_: [PubMed](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9149062/), [EPA](https://archive.epa.gov/water/archive/web/html/sulfate.html) # Primo Full Water Testing Report | Chemical | Status | FDA SOQ (mg/L) | | ---------------------------------------------------- | ------ | -------------- | | **Inorganic Chemicals** | | Antimony | ND | 0.006 | | Arsenic | ND | 0.005 | | Barium | ND | 2 | | Beryllium | ND | 0.004 | | Bromate | ND | 0.010 | | Cadmium | ND | 0.005 | | Chlorine, Free | ND | 4.0 | | Chloramine | ND | 4.0 | | Chlorine dioxide | ND | 0.8 | | Chlorite | ND | 1.0 | | Chromium | ND | 0.1 | | Cyanide | ND | 0.1 | | Fluoride | ND | 1.3 | | Lead | ND | 0.005 | | Mercury | ND | 0.002 | | Nickel | ND | 0.1 | | Nitrate-N | ND | 10 | | Nitrite-N | ND | 1 | | Total Nitrate + Nitrite | ND | 10 | | title: Pure Life water quality report
description: Nestle Pure Life water quality and ingredients.

body.raw: ## Pure Life Overview **Oaisys score:** 70 / 100 **Owner and Manufacturer**: Nestlé Waters North America **Treatment process**: Reverse osmosis, UV and ozone disinfection for added safety assurance and enhanced with minerals for consistent and pleasing taste **Source**: Las Jaras, Herrera Del Duque, Badajoz, Spain **pH level**: 7.8 at Lightwood source and 6.5 at Oakwood source. **Flouride level**: 0.0 ppm ## Pure Life Ingredients - Calcium Chloride - Sodium Bicarbonate - Magnesium Sulfate **Effects of Calcium Chloride** Calcium chloride (CaCl2), commonly found in water, dissociates into calcium and chloride ions when consumed. These ions are independently regulated in the body and contribute to various physiological functions. It's essential to understand the impact of calcium chloride on human health in the context of drinking water consumption. Benefits of Calcium Chloride - **Calcium Contribution**: Calcium is vital for bone and teeth formation and maintenance. It plays a crucial role in blood coagulation, neuromuscular activity, enzyme activity, and acid-base balance. - **Chloride Contribution**: Chloride maintains osmotic and acid-base balance in the body, predominantly existing in extracellular fluids. Harms of Calcium Chloride - **Low Acute Toxicity**: Calcium chloride demonstrates low acute toxicity in oral exposure, but high doses can lead to adverse effects. - **Gastrointestinal Irritation**: In some animal studies, high doses have led to severe ulceration and perforation of the stomach. - **Skin and Eye Irritation**: Exposure to anhydrous calcium chloride can severely irritate the eyes and cause skin lesions in case of repeated contact with concentrated solutions. - **Respiratory Irritation**: While the reliability of certain studies is questioned, some evidence suggests that calcium chloride can cause slight respiratory irritation. Interactions and Safety - **Dissociation in Water**: When consumed in drinking water, calcium chloride dissociates into calcium and chloride ions, which are absorbed efficiently and regulated separately. - **Safety in Low Concentrations**: In consumer products like cosmetics, calcium chloride in aqueous solutions poses a low risk of eye irritation, suggesting that at low concentrations, it might not present significant health risks. Calcium chloride, when consumed in drinking water, contributes essential calcium and chloride ions for various body functions. While it shows low acute toxicity, high concentrations can lead to gastrointestinal, skin, and eye irritation. It's crucial to monitor the concentration levels in drinking water to harness its benefits while mitigating potential harms. _Sources_: [PubMed: Calcium Chloride in Drinking Water](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9827598/), [EWG: Calcium Chloride](https://www.ewg.org/guides/substances/895-CALCIUMCHLORIDE/), [Industrial Chemicals: Calcium Chloride Human Health Assessment](https://www.industrialchemicals.gov.au/sites/default/files/Calcium%20chloride%20%28CaCl2%29_Human%20health%20tier%20II%20assessment.pdf) **Sodium Bicarbonate** Sodium Bicarbonate, commonly known as baking soda, is a compound that dissolves in water to form sodium and bicarbonate, creating an alkaline solution. This attribute has made it a popular choice for various health-related uses. Let's delve into its impact when consumed in drinking water: - **Neutralizes Stomach Acid**: Its ability to neutralize acid can alleviate conditions like indigestion, which arises from excess stomach acid. This property is beneficial for those suffering from heartburn, providing temporary relief. - **Oral Health**: Small clinical trials have indicated that a sodium bicarbonate rinse can increase saliva pH, making it less acidic. This is crucial for maintaining dental enamel and may be beneficial for individuals with mouth sores or undergoing treatments like chemotherapy. - **Athletic Performance**: Some studies suggest that sodium bicarbonate supplements can enhance performance in high-intensity exercises. However, it's important to note that these effects might also be partly attributed to the placebo effect. - **Kidney Health**: In cases of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease, sodium bicarbonate can help reverse blood acidity. This might slow the progression of chronic kidney disease, although more research is needed for conclusive evidence. Potential Side Effects - **Gastrointestinal Discomfort**: Common side effects include abdominal bloating, nausea, and stomach pain. In some cases, these symptoms can become severe. - **Allergic Reactions**: Although rare, severe allergic reactions to sodium bicarbonate are possible, manifesting as breathing difficulties, itchiness, and rashes. - **Contraindications**: It is advised to avoid sodium bicarbonate for those on sodium-restricted diets, as it increases sodium levels in the bloodstream. Also, excessive use can lead to kidney problems and should be used cautiously, especially in individuals with existing kidney conditions. - **Pregnancy and Breastfeeding**: There is limited data on its safety during pregnancy and breastfeeding. Pregnant individuals may experience fluid buildup and low blood acid levels, making it important to consult healthcare providers before use. Sodium bicarbonate in drinking water can offer several health benefits, particularly in neutralizing stomach acid and improving oral health. However, it's important to be aware of potential side effects and consult with healthcare professionals, especially in cases of existing health conditions or dietary restrictions. _Sources_:[Sodium Bicarbonate - Mayo Clinic](https://www.mayoclinic.org/drugs-supplements/sodium-bicarbonate-oral-route-intravenous-route-subcutaneous-route/side-effects/drg-20065950?p=1) **Effects of Magnesium Sulfate** Magnesium sulfate, commonly found in drinking water, is essential for human health. Let's explore the impact of consuming magnesium sulfate through drinking water: Key Advantages of Magnesium in Drinking Water: - **Heart Health Support:** Magnesium plays a critical role in heart muscle function and the energy dynamics within heart cells. Research indicates that a magnesium-rich diet can help in preventing heart diseases and assist in managing existing cardiac conditions. Regular intake of magnesium through water could potentially lower the risk of heart complications following a heart attack. - **Thrombosis Prevention:** As an anti-thrombotic element, magnesium lowers the likelihood of blood clots. This is particularly beneficial for people with heart diseases, where blood clots pose a significant threat. - **Regulating Electrolytes:** Being a crucial electrolyte, magnesium aids in balancing other vital electrolytes like potassium and calcium, influencing various body functions. Potential Downsides of Magnesium in Drinking Water: - **Risks of High Intake:** Though uncommon, an excessive intake of magnesium from all sources, including water, might lead to hypermagnesemia, particularly in those with compromised kidney functions. Symptoms might include nausea, vomiting, and decreased blood pressure. - **Medication Interactions:** Magnesium can interfere with certain medications, impacting their effectiveness. Individuals on medication should monitor their magnesium consumption. In essence, magnesium in drinking water primarily offers positive contributions to our daily nutritional needs. The significance of magnesium in promoting heart health and maintaining electrolyte balance underscores its importance in our diet, typically acquired safely through water consumption. _Sources_: [PubMed: Magnesium in Drinking Water](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5786912/), [PubMed: Magnesium and Heart Health](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32389435/), [Healthline: Epsom Salt Benefits and Uses](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/epsom-salt-benefits-uses#bottom-line), [PubMed: Magnesium and Electrolyte Balance](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7911806/), [PubMed: Magnesium and Thrombosis Prevention](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7400933/), [PubMed: Magnesium and Medication Interactions](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554553/) # Pure Life Full Testing Report A 2017 water analysis report for Nestle PureLife is listed below. title: Smartwater Quality Test Report
description: Breaking down what's inside Smartwater and how it affects your health, with a water quality test report.

body.raw: ## Smartwater Overview **Oaisys score:** 71 / 100 **Owner and Manufacturer**: Coca-Cola Company. **Treatment process**: vapor distillation process which attempts to replicate nature's hydrologic cycle. The vapor-distilled water then undergoes a proprietary filtration process. **Source**: Most facilities obtain the water from municipal water systems. A Few get the water from protected groundwater sources with approvals from local authorities **pH level**: 9.5 **Flouride level**: 0.0 ppm ## Smartwater Ingredients - Calcium Chloride: - Magnesium Chloride - Potassium Bicarbonate - Electrolytes **Effects of Calcium Chloride** Calcium chloride (CaCl2), commonly found in water, dissociates into calcium and chloride ions when consumed. These ions are independently regulated in the body and contribute to various physiological functions. It's essential to understand the impact of calcium chloride on human health in the context of drinking water consumption. Benefits of Calcium Chloride - **Calcium Contribution**: Calcium is vital for bone and teeth formation and maintenance. It plays a crucial role in blood coagulation, neuromuscular activity, enzyme activity, and acid-base balance. - **Chloride Contribution**: Chloride maintains osmotic and acid-base balance in the body, predominantly existing in extracellular fluids. Harms of Calcium Chloride - **Low Acute Toxicity**: Calcium chloride demonstrates low acute toxicity in oral exposure, but high doses can lead to adverse effects. - **Gastrointestinal Irritation**: In some animal studies, high doses have led to severe ulceration and perforation of the stomach. - **Skin and Eye Irritation**: Exposure to anhydrous calcium chloride can severely irritate the eyes and cause skin lesions in case of repeated contact with concentrated solutions. - **Respiratory Irritation**: While the reliability of certain studies is questioned, some evidence suggests that calcium chloride can cause slight respiratory irritation. Interactions and Safety - **Dissociation in Water**: When consumed in drinking water, calcium chloride dissociates into calcium and chloride ions, which are absorbed efficiently and regulated separately. - **Safety in Low Concentrations**: In consumer products like cosmetics, calcium chloride in aqueous solutions poses a low risk of eye irritation, suggesting that at low concentrations, it might not present significant health risks. Calcium chloride, when consumed in drinking water, contributes essential calcium and chloride ions for various body functions. While it shows low acute toxicity, high concentrations can lead to gastrointestinal, skin, and eye irritation. It's crucial to monitor the concentration levels in drinking water to harness its benefits while mitigating potential harms. _Sources_: [PubMed: Calcium Chloride in Drinking Water](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9827598/), [EWG: Calcium Chloride](https://www.ewg.org/guides/substances/895-CALCIUMCHLORIDE/), [Industrial Chemicals: Calcium Chloride Human Health Assessment](https://www.industrialchemicals.gov.au/sites/default/files/Calcium%20chloride%20%28CaCl2%29_Human%20health%20tier%20II%20assessment.pdf) Effects of Magnesium Chloride **Magnesium Chloride** Magnesium Chloride, a blend of magnesium and chloride, is not just a mere ingredient but a conduit to enhanced health when present in drinking water. Benefits - **Essential for Bodily Functions**: Magnesium is pivotal for muscle and nerve function, regulating blood sugar and blood pressure, and is involved in the synthesis of protein, bones, and DNA. - **Promotes Bone Health**: A key player in bone formation, maintaining optimal magnesium levels is crucial for bone density and overall skeletal integrity. - **Regulates Blood Pressure**: Studies indicate that magnesium can have a modest effect in managing blood pressure, a boon for those grappling with hypertension. - **Diabetes Management**: Magnesium plays a role in managing blood sugar levels, potentially benefiting individuals with type 2 diabetes by improving insulin sensitivity. - **Migraine Relief**: Evidence suggests that magnesium can be an effective agent in preventing migraines, offering relief to those suffering from this debilitating condition. - **Sleep and Mood Enhancement**: Adequate magnesium levels are associated with better sleep quality and mood regulation, contributing to overall well-being. Harms - **Digestive Upsets**: Excessive intake can lead to gastrointestinal issues like stomach upset, nausea, and diarrhea. - **Rare but Serious Risks**: In extreme cases, too much magnesium can cause more severe symptoms like hypotension, dizziness, and confusion. - **Interactions with Medications**: Magnesium can interact with various medications, necessitating consultation with healthcare providers for those on medication regimes. - **Individual Variability**: Effects can vary greatly depending on individual health conditions and dietary habits. In essence, while Magnesium Chloride in drinking water can be a health ally, its consumption must be balanced and tailored to individual needs. The key is moderation and awareness of one’s own health profile. _Sources:_ [Magnesium Consumer](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Magnesium-Consumer/), [Hypertension](https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/HYPERTENSIONAHA.116.07664), [Nature](https://www.nature.com/articles/ejcn20124), [Verywell Health](https://www.verywellhealth.com/magnesium-chloride-4768643#citation-17), [MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/12/7/2104), [RxList](https://www.rxlist.com/magnesium_chloride/generic-drug.htm) **Potassium Bicarbonate** Potassium Bicarbonate is more than just a component of drinking water; it's a key player in our overall well-being. This alkaline mineral is crucial for various bodily functions, from keeping our hearts beating strong to ensuring our muscles work seamlessly. It's like the unsung hero of the mineral world, quietly making a significant impact on our health. But, as with all things, moderation is key. Here's a breakdown of its benefits and considerations: Benefits of Potassium Bicarbonate: - **Heart Health Maverick:** This mineral is a boon for our hearts. It not only keeps the heartbeat in check but also supports muscular contractions, essential for a healthy cardiovascular system. High potassium intake, coupled with low salt, can be a game-changer for blood pressure management. - **Guardian of Bones:** Here's a fact that might surprise you - Potassium Bicarbonate is a bone health champion. It fights off calcium loss, thereby keeping bones robust and sturdy, particularly crucial as we age. - **Muscle Functionality:** Ever wondered what helps your muscles contract and avoid cramps? Potassium Bicarbonate is the answer. It's vital for maintaining muscle strength and functionality. - **Kidney Stone Dissolver:** Struggling with kidney stones? Potassium Bicarbonate might come to your rescue by dissolving those pesky stones formed by uric acid. - **Potassium Level Balancer:** For those moments when your body is running low on potassium due to health issues, this mineral can help bring things back to equilibrium. Important Considerations: - **Hyperkalemia Hazard:** More isn't always better. Too much Potassium Bicarbonate can lead to hyperkalemia, which is as dangerous as it sounds, with symptoms like dizziness and even cardiac arrest. - **Medication Interactions:** If you're on medication, especially for blood pressure or kidney issues, a chat with your healthcare provider before embracing this supplement is a must. - **Not for Everyone:** Certain health conditions like kidney disease or Addison's disease? Pregnant or nursing? It's best to steer clear of Potassium Bicarbonate or seek medical advice first. - **Dosage Matters:** Remember, even a good thing can be harmful in excess. Stick to the recommended dosage to reap the benefits without the risks. In essence, Potassium Bicarbonate is a potent ally for our health, but it demands respect and careful usage. It's a perfect example of how balance and moderation are key to harnessing the benefits of nature's offerings. _Sources_: [Source 1](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2630872/), [Source 2](https://www.accessdata.fda.gov/scripts/cdrh/cfdocs/cfcfr/CFRSearch.cfm?fr=184.1613), [Source 3](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4817273/pdf/nihms769011.pdf), [Source 4](https://www.ahajournals.org/doi/10.1161/hypertensionaha.109.147488), [Source 5](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28073209/), [Source 6](https://www.healthline.com/health/potassium-bicarbonate#takeaway) ## Smartwater Full Testing Report A 2018 sample water quality analysis for smartwater is listed below. Please note that in the results column of each table “ND” indicates Non-Detected. **Residual Disinfectants** | Standard of Quality (mg/L) | Results (mg/L) | | -------------------------- | -------------- | | Chloramine (4) | ND | | Chlorine (4) | ND | | Chlorine Dioxide (0.8) | ND | **Radionuclides** | Standard of Quality (pCi/L) | Results (pCi/L) | | ---------------------------------- | --------------- | | Gross Alpha particle activity (15) | ND | | Gross Beta particle (50) | ND | | Radium 226 (3) | ND | | Radium 228 (5) | ND | | Uranium (0.03 mg/L) | ND | **Microbiological** | Standard of Quality | Results | | ------------------------ | ----------------------------------- | | Coliform (< 4 CFU/100mL) | Absent (Membrane Filtration Method) | **Physical Quality** | Standard of Quality | Results | | ------------------- | ------- | | Color (15 Units) | Pass | | Odor (3) | Pass | | Turbidity (5 Units) | Pass | **Organic Components** | Standard of Quality (mg/L) | Results (mg/L) | | ---------------------------- | -------------- | | Aluminum (0.2) | ND | | Antimony (0.006) | ND | | Arsenic (0.01) | ND | | Barium (2) | ND | | Beryllium (0.004) | ND | | Cadmium (0.005) | ND | | Chloride (250) | Pass | | Chromium (0.1) | ND | | Copper (1) | ND | | Cyanide (0.2) | ND | | Fluoride (1.4 – 2.4) | ND | | Iron (0.3) | ND | | Lead (0.005) | ND | | Manganese (0.05) | ND | | Mercury (0.002) | ND | | Nitrate (as N) (10) | Pass | | Nitrite (as N) (1) | ND | | Phenols (0.001) | ND | | Selenium (0.05) | ND | | Silver (0.1) | ND | | Sulfate (250) | ND | | Thallium (0.002) | ND | | Total Dissolved Solids (500) | Pass | ## Smartwater Oaisys Page [See full report](https://www.oaisys.ai/blog/smartwater_quality_reportt) ## Sources [Water Report](https://article.images.consumerreports.org/image/upload/prod/pdf/cq_water_reports/SmartWater_2018.pdf)

title: Toxic Chemicals found in Tap Water
description: Tap water supplies are often filled with many toxic and harmful chemicals.

body.raw: Depending on where you live, tap water sources are often filled with many toxic and harmful chemicals. These are a list of common ones found throughout the United Steas and their effects on your health. Please note: this is not a complete list nor does it suggest all of these chemicals are in your water. **Alachlore**: Associated with increased cancer risk and liver, kidney, spleen, eye, and nose damage. **Arsenic**: Long-term exposure can lead to skin, bladder, and lung cancers; skin discoloration and lesions. **Atrazine**: May disrupt endocrine system, linked to birth defects and reproductive disorders. **Bromate**: Potential carcinogen and mutagenic (causes mutations in DNA). **Benzenee**: Known carcinogen; can cause bone marrow failure, anemia, and leukemia. **Cadmium**: Kidney damage and bone demineralization; linked to respiratory and prostate cancer. **Carbon Tetrachloride**: Liver, kidney, and central nervous system damage; potential carcinogen. **Chlordanee**: Affects nervous system, digestive system, and liver; potential carcinogen. **Chlorobenzene**: Can damage liver, kidney, and central nervous system. **Chloropicrin**: Eye and respiratory irritant; can cause lung damage. **Chromium**: anemia, thrombocytopenia, skin conditions, liver dysfunction, renal failure, rhabdomyolysis, dermatitis, hypoglycemia and stomach cancers. **Copper**: High levels can cause gastrointestinal distress and liver or kidney damage. **Dibromochloropropane**: Testicular damage and infertility; possible carcinogen. **p-Dichlorobenzene**: May harm liver and kidneys; possibly carcinogenic. **1,2-Dichloroethane**: Can cause liver and kidney damage; likely carcinogen. **1,1-Dichloroethylene**: Potential effects on liver and nervous system; possibly carcinogenic. **cis-1,2-Dichloroethylene**: May affect liver; data on health effects limited. **trans-1,2-Dichloroethylene**: Limited data, but potential liver and lung effects. **1,2-Dichloropropane**: Associated with increased cancer risk. **Dinoseb**: Can affect thyroid and reproductive system; potential carcinogen. **Endrin**: Affects nervous system; can cause convulsions and headaches. **Ethylbenzene**: May cause liver, kidney, and central nervous system damage. **Ethylene dibromide (EDB)**: Highly toxic; affects the lungs, stomach, and reproductive system. **Haloacetonitriles (HAN)**: Potential carcinogens; can affect liver and kidneys. Haloacetic acids (HAA9): Haloacetic acids are formed when substances such as chlorine are added to tap water. Found to increase the risk of cancer and may impair fetal growth and development. Haloacetic acids (HAA9): Haloacetic acids are formed when substances such as chlorine are added to tap water. Found to increase the risk of cancer. **1,1,1-trichloro-2-propanone**: Limited data, but may be carcinogenic. **Heptachlor epoxide**: Liver damage and increased cancer risk. **Hexachlorocyclopentadiene**: Irritation to the eyes, skin, and respiratory system. **Mercury**: Affects the nervous system, particularly in fetuses and young children. **Nitrate**: Cancer risk, thyroid disease, adverse reproductive outcomes, can cause "blue baby syndrome" and affect oxygen transport in blood. **Nitrite**: Similar effects as nitrate; possible cancer risk. **p-Dichlorobenzene**: Potential liver and kidney effects; data limited. **Perfluorooctanoic Acid (PFOA)**: Linked to cancer, liver damage, and developmental effects. **Perfluorooctane Sulfonate (PFOS)**: May affect cholesterol levels, liver, and thyroid. **Radium**: Increased risk of bone cancer; affects teeth and bones. **Simazine**: Endocrine disruptor; potential carcinogen. **Styrene**: Possible effects on the nervous system; may affect hearing and vision. **Tetrachloroethylene**: Neurological effects, kidney and liver damage; likely carcinogen. **Toluene**: Affects the nervous system; can cause kidney and liver damage. **1,1,1-Trichloroethane**: Central nervous system depressant; may affect liver and kidneys. **Trichloroethylene**: Can cause liver, kidney, and immune system damage; probable carcinogen. **Trihalomethanes (THMs)**: Linked to bladder and colorectal cancer; may affect liver, kidney, and central nervous system. **Uranium**: Kidney damage, respiratory irritation and accumalation of fluid in the lungs, and increased risk of cancer.. **Xylenes**: Affect the central nervous system; can cause liver and kidney damage. ## Sources [Bromate](https://dhss.delaware.gov/dhss/dph/files/bromatefaq.pdf) [Chromium](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/Chromium-HealthProfessional/#:~:text=According%20to%20isolated%20case%20reports,hypoglycemia%20%5B73%2C74%5D.) [Nitrate](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6068531/) [Nitrite](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7139399/) [Uranium](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK158804/)
